utterances: Roth directs the National Institute of Mental Health Psychoactive Drug Screening Program and his lab discovered how salvia divinorum interacts uniquely with the brain.
He says it affects users very differently than LSD or any other hallucinogenic drug.
And, in essence, what happens when users take a sufficient dose is that they're transported nearly instantaneously to an alternative universe, a different place and time.
And frequently they have no memory actually of having ingested a drug.
Roth says the dream-like or visionary experience is too intense and not enjoyable for many first-time users.
Another expert on salvia, Daniel Siebert, who has grown, researched, sold and used the herb himself, agrees salvia is not for everyone.
Most people who do it hoping to just have a interesting high find it confusing and disappointing.
It's not something that's fun to do.
It doesn't have a stimulating effect.
It doesn't really have a euphoric effect.
For that reason, Siebert doubts salvia will every catch on as a recreational drug.
But he too is concerned about the way it's being marketed on some web sites and in some shops misleading as producing marijuana-like affects.
Siebert says salvia appeals to people he calls spiritual seekers who use it in meditation.
He calls it an extraordinary tool for delving into one's psyche and as a way to find a greater internal sense of awareness.

That's closer to the traditional use of this type of sage, which is found naturally in the mountains of the Ohaka region of southern Mexico, where the Mazatec Indians used it for centuries to divine the spirits in religious ceremonies and for medicinal purposes.
The effects of salvia don't last long.
The most intense trips last no more than 15 minutes and the full effects wear off after about an hour.
Though not conclusive, Roth says preliminary research finds Salvia does not appear to be addictive nor toxic, but he says there may be at least one negative side effect.
There is good reason to suspect, from animal studies which have been done with this and related compounds, that it may cause a depressive-like experience or syndrome in individuals.
Roth cannot say conclusively that Salvia use leads to depression in humans, but he and other salvia researchers report anecdotal evidence.
And some Salvia users themselves say they've felt depressed after taking salvia, some for a period of days.
Kathy Chitister (ph) of Wilmington, Delaware believes salvia may have affected her 17-year-old son Brett in that way.
She says a relative told her last August that Brett was using salvia and after reading up on it on the internet, she confronted him.
And I asked him to please stop.
The bag that I found, I dumped that down the toilet.
And he had said at that point that he would not do it anymore.

Chitister's says she knows now that Brett didn't stop using Salvia and on Monday, January 23rd, after spending the weekend working on college applications and talking with his girlfriend about marriage after college, the straight-A student took his own life.
Chitister says after Brett's suicide, she discovered receipts for Internet purchases of Salvia.
And she says she also found an essay he'd written about his salvia experiences on his computer.
In it, she says, Brett wrote that tripping on Salvia allowed him to give up his senses and wander into the inter-dimensional time and space.
He wrote that he discovered the secrets to the universe, that there are other worlds and that earthly human existence is pointless.
And what it boiled down to at the end was that we really had no use in this life.
Chitister says that essay echoes what Brett wrote in his suicide note.
Pathologists are trying to determine if Brett had salvia in his system when he died.
Officials at the Delaware State Medical Examiner's office say they never heard of salvia before Brett's death and are now attempting to test for it.
Even if that's successful, a spokesman says trying to connect salvia to Brett's suicide is like trying to connect use of LSD or any other hallucinogenic drug to suicide: it's difficult at best.
Chitister says she isn't certain salvia led her son to take his own life, but she searches and just can't come up with any other answers.
So she wants the sale, possession and use of the drug banned.
Brett was my only child and I definitely don't want any other parents to go through what I have gone through.
A bill to outlaw salvia, to be dubbed Brett's Law, is being introduced in the Delaware legislature this month.
Two other states, Missouri and Louisiana, have already banned salvia, as have Australia, Italy, Denmark and a few other nations.
The U.S.
Drug Enforcement Agency lists salvia as "a drug of concern.
A spokeswoman wouldn't discuss salvia on air, but said just because it's legal doesn't mean it's safe for recreational use.
Legislation to make it a controlled substance has failed twice in Congress.
David Schaper, NPR News, Chicago.
This is News & Notes.
I'm Tony Cox.
Meeting up with old school pals can be a pleasure or a real pain.
This would appear to be the case for some, at least, on the second season of the TV reality show High School Reunion.
The class of 1988 from Arizona's Chandler High School gathered on the romantic island of Kauai but it wasn't really a love-in for all involved.
(Soundbite of TV show ""High School Reunion"")

(bleep) the point that you're trying to make.
That was Dennis, the so-called troublemaker, ruffling the feathers of his former housemates.
His comment was directed towards Shalonda Warren-Clark.
And she joins us know.

How are you?

His role was to come in and shake it up.
But I don't think that, you know - so I looked at him as like being a hornet in a jar, and they shook it up and shook it up and let the lid off.
But they did know that he, you know, had so much venom.
But it's just something that I don't find tolerable.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Daniel Yergin of Cambridge Energy Research Associates says gas prices are up because of the West's confrontation with Iran and sanctions over its nuclear program.
Right now, the market focus is on a tightening of supply because the whole direction of these policies is to do one thing, which is to reduce Iran's ability to export oil.
That's driven crude oil prices in the U.S.
to around $106 a barrel.
But Fadel Gheit, senior energy analyst at the investment firm Oppenheimer and Company, says there's an even bigger reason than Iran.
The supply of gasoline has been declining because we have 700,000 barrels of refining capacity were shut in in the last three months.
That is almost 5 percent of U.S.
gasoline production is now offline.
This is just an amazing drop in refining capacity.
That's energy analyst Phil Verleger.
I've been following the industry since 1971 and never in my life have I seen so many refineries close all at once.
Sunoco, Conoco and Hess have all retired outmoded, unprofitable refineries in the eastern U.S.
and Caribbean.
And Verleger says a big European refinery that produced gasoline that was exported to the U.S.
has also closed.
But there's still another interesting ingredient to add to this gas price stew, says Fadel Gheit.
Because the global market is much more lucrative than the domestic market, for the first time in our history, we are not importing gasoline.
Not only are we not importing gasoline, we're actually a net exporter of gasoline.
So while gasoline supplies are short and prices are rising in the U.S., the big oil companies are exporting gasoline.
Ironically, that's because natural gas prices in the United States are so low.
U.S.
refiners are using this cheap, domestic natural gas to produce the heat needed to crack crude oil into products like gasoline.
That enables us to land gasoline in Mexico, for example, cheaper than Mexican refiners can produce it for.
It's part of the very surprising energy advantage the U.S.
is developing because of techniques like fracking and horizontal drilling.
They're producing once unimaginable amounts of natural gas inside the U.S.
But will the higher oil and gasoline prices stall the U.S.
recovery?
Dan Yergin thinks they could.
Every penny increase in the price of gasoline takes a billion dollars out of the pockets of consumers over a year.
That could hurt spending and cost jobs across the economy.
But Phil Verleger is more optimistic.
For the first time in my life, I'd say that this time higher oil prices may actually stimulate a little more economic activity rather than a little less economic activity.
Verleger says that's because the higher prices are causing many people to buy fuel-efficient cars, boosting the output in one of the country's major industries.
John Ydstie, NPR News, Washington.
It's WEEKENDS on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Guy Raz.
